forecast.review: Forecasters 2 and 3 make a strong, status-quo–anchored case: months of polling with a sizeable CPC lead, Liberals in the low-to-mid 20s, and structural regional constraints (Bloc in Quebec, NDP in urban cores) render 172+ a deep right-tail outcome. They also rightly note that under FPTP, a Liberal majority typically requires high-30s national vote share with highly favorable Ontario/Quebec splits—well beyond current indicators. Their emphasis on model upper tails (i.e., majority probability effectively near-zero today) is persuasive and highlights that my prior 12% overweighted tail scenarios. They also flag the inconsistency in the research assistant’s 338Canada note; without corroboration, it should be discounted. I find their arguments convincing and materially update downward.
forecast.rationale: Time to election is roughly six months, and the status quo shows Liberals far from majority conditions. Achieving ≥172 seats would require: (1) a double-digit national recovery to ~38–40%+, (2) dominant margins in Ontario suburbs, (3) a meaningful Quebec rebound at the Bloc’s expense, and (4) strong results in Atlantic Canada and gains in BC—all while reversing incumbent-fatigue and unfavorable leader ratings. Such a synchronized, multi-region surge is possible but rare in this timeframe. Given persistent adverse fundamentals and model consensus (as reported by peers) placing the Liberal majority well into the upper tail, I now assign only a small probability to the Yes outcome. I would move up if sustained polling shows the race tied or Liberals leading nationally, clear Liberal leads in Ontario (e.g., +6 or more), visible Bloc erosion with Liberals >30% in Quebec, leader favorability improvement, and reputable models giving a double-digit probability of a Liberal majority. Absent those, the baseline points strongly to No.
